children.description: The maximum space in bytes than an individual message may take, messages larger than this value will be rejected. This field corresponds to Kafka's `max.message.bytes`.

children.name: broker_write_max_bytes
children.description: The upper bound for the number of bytes written to a broker connection in a single write. This field corresponds to Kafka's `socket.request.max.bytes`.

outputs.name: mongodb
outputs.summary: Inserts items into a MongoDB collection.
outputs.description:
== Performance

This output benefits from sending multiple messages in flight in parallel for improved performance. You can tune the max number of in flight messages (or message batches) with the field `max_in_flight`.

This output benefits from sending messages as a batch for improved performance. Batches can be formed at both the input and output level. You can find out more xref:configuration:batching.adoc[in this doc].

children.name: url
children.description: The URL of the target MongoDB server.

children.name: database
children.description: The name of the target MongoDB database.

children.name: username
children.description: The username to connect to the database.

children.name: password
children.description: The password to connect to the database.

children.name: app_name
children.description: The client application name.

children.name: collection
children.description: The name of the target collection.

children.name: operation
children.description: The mongodb operation to perform.

children.name: write_concern
children.description: The write concern settings for the mongo connection.

children.name: w
children.description: W requests acknowledgement that write operations propagate to the specified number of mongodb instances. Can be the string "majority" to wait for a calculated majority of nodes to acknowledge the write operation, or an integer value specifying an minimum number of nodes to acknowledge the operation, or a string specifying the name of a custom write concern configured in the cluster.

children.name: j
children.description: J requests acknowledgement from MongoDB that write operations are written to the journal.

children.name: w_timeout
children.description: The write concern timeout.

children.name: document_map
children.description: A bloblang map representing a document to store within MongoDB, expressed as https://www.mongodb.com/docs/manual/reference/mongodb-extended-json/[extended JSON in canonical form^]. The document map is required for the operations insert-one, replace-one, update-one and aggregate.

children.name: filter_map
children.description: A bloblang map representing a filter for a MongoDB command, expressed as https://www.mongodb.com/docs/manual/reference/mongodb-extended-json/[extended JSON in canonical form^]. The filter map is required for all operations except insert-one. It is used to find the document(s) for the operation. For example in a delete-one case, the filter map should have the fields required to locate the document to delete.

children.name: hint_map
children.description: A bloblang map representing the hint for the MongoDB command, expressed as https://www.mongodb.com/docs/manual/reference/mongodb-extended-json/[extended JSON in canonical form^]. This map is optional and is used with all operations except insert-one. It is used to improve performance of finding the documents in the mongodb.

children.name: upsert
children.description: The upsert setting is optional and only applies for update-one and replace-one operations. If the filter specified in filter_map matches, the document is updated or replaced accordingly, otherwise it is created.

children.name: max_in_flight
children.description: The maximum number of messages to have in flight at a given time. Increase this to improve throughput.

children.name: batching
children.description: Allows you to configure a xref:configuration:batching.adoc[batching policy].

children.name: count
children.description: A number of messages at which the batch should be flushed. If `0` disables count based batching.

children.name: byte_size
children.description: An amount of bytes at which the batch should be flushed. If `0` disables size based batching.

children.name: period
children.description: A period in which an incomplete batch should be flushed regardless of its size.

children.name: check
children.description: A xref:guides:bloblang/about.adoc[Bloblang query] that should return a boolean value indicating whether a message should end a batch.

children.name: processors
children.description: A list of xref:components:processors/about.adoc[processors] to apply to a batch as it is flushed. This allows you to aggregate and archive the batch however you see fit. Please note that all resulting messages are flushed as a single batch, therefore splitting the batch into smaller batches using these processors is a no-op.

children.name: max_retries
children.description: The maximum number of retries before giving up on the request. If set to zero there is no discrete limit.

children.name: backoff
children.description: Control time intervals between retry attempts.

children.name: initial_interval
children.description: The initial period to wait between retry attempts.

children.name: max_interval
children.description: The maximum period to wait between retry attempts.

children.name: max_elapsed_time
children.description: The maximum period to wait before retry attempts are abandoned. If zero then no limit is used.

outputs.name: mqtt
outputs.summary: Pushes messages to an MQTT broker.
outputs.description:
The `topic` field can be dynamically set using function interpolations described xref:configuration:interpolation.adoc#bloblang-queries[here]. When sending batched messages these interpolations are performed per message part.

== Performance

This output benefits from sending multiple messages in flight in parallel for improved performance. You can tune the max number of in flight messages (or message batches) with the field `max_in_flight`.

children.name: urls
children.description: A list of URLs to connect to. The format should be `scheme://host:port` where `scheme` is one of `tcp`, `ssl`, or `ws`, `host` is the ip-address (or hostname) and `port` is the port on which the broker is accepting connections. If an item of the list contains commas it will be expanded into multiple URLs.

children.name: client_id
children.description: An identifier for the client connection.

children.name: dynamic_client_id_suffix
children.description: Append a dynamically generated suffix to the specified `client_id` on each run of the pipeline. This can be useful when clustering Redpanda Connect producers.
annotated_options: append a nanoid of length 21 characters
children.linter: root = []

children.name: connect_timeout
children.description: The maximum amount of time to wait in order to establish a connection before the attempt is abandoned.

children.name: will
children.description: Set last will message in case of Redpanda Connect failure

children.name: enabled
children.description: Whether to enable last will messages.

children.name: qos
children.description: Set QoS for last will message. Valid values are: 0, 1, 2.

children.name: retained
children.description: Set retained for last will message.

children.name: topic
children.description: Set topic for last will message.

children.name: payload
children.description: Set payload for last will message.

children.name: user
children.description: A username to connect with.

children.name: password
children.description: A password to connect with.

children.name: keepalive
children.description: Max seconds of inactivity before a keepalive message is sent.

children.name: tls
children.description: Custom TLS settings can be used to override system defaults.

children.name: enabled
children.description: Whether custom TLS settings are enabled.

children.name: skip_cert_verify
children.description: Whether to skip server side certificate verification.

children.name: enable_renegotiation
children.description: Whether to allow the remote server to repeatedly request renegotiation. Enable this option if you're seeing the error message `local error: tls: no renegotiation`.

children.name: root_cas
children.description: An optional root certificate authority to use. This is a string, representing a certificate chain from the parent trusted root certificate, to possible intermediate signing certificates, to the host certificate.

children.name: root_cas_file
children.description: An optional path of a root certificate authority file to use. This is a file, often with a .pem extension, containing a certificate chain from the parent trusted root certificate, to possible intermediate signing certificates, to the host certificate.

children.name: client_certs
children.description: A list of client certificates to use. For each certificate either the fields `cert` and `key`, or `cert_file` and `key_file` should be specified, but not both.

children.name: cert
children.description: A plain text certificate to use.

children.name: key
children.description: A plain text certificate key to use.

children.name: cert_file
children.description: The path of a certificate to use.

children.name: key_file
children.description: The path of a certificate key to use.

children.name: password
children.description:
A plain text password for when the private key is password encrypted in PKCS#1 or PKCS#8 format. The obsolete `pbeWithMD5AndDES-CBC` algorithm is not supported for the PKCS#8 format.

Because the obsolete pbeWithMD5AndDES-CBC algorithm does not authenticate the ciphertext, it is vulnerable to padding oracle attacks that can let an attacker recover the plaintext.

children.name: topic
children.description: The topic to publish messages to.

children.name: qos
children.description: The QoS value to set for each message. Has options 0, 1, 2.

children.name: write_timeout
children.description: The maximum amount of time to wait to write data before the attempt is abandoned.

children.name: retained
children.description: Set message as retained on the topic.

children.name: retained_interpolated
children.description: Override the value of `retained` with an interpolable value, this allows it to be dynamically set based on message contents. The value must resolve to either `true` or `false`.

children.name: max_in_flight
children.description: The maximum number of messages to have in flight at a given time. Increase this to improve throughput.

outputs.name: nanomsg
outputs.summary: Send messages over a Nanomsg socket.
outputs.description:
Currently only PUSH and PUB sockets are supported.

== Performance

This output benefits from sending multiple messages in flight in parallel for improved performance. You can tune the max number of in flight messages (or message batches) with the field `max_in_flight`.

children.name: urls
children.description: A list of URLs to connect to. If an item of the list contains commas it will be expanded into multiple URLs.

children.name: bind
children.description: Whether the URLs listed should be bind (otherwise they are connected to).

children.name: socket_type
children.description: The socket type to send with.

children.name: poll_timeout
children.description: The maximum period of time to wait for a message to send before the request is abandoned and reattempted.

children.name: max_in_flight
children.description: The maximum number of messages to have in flight at a given time. Increase this to improve throughput.

outputs.name: nats
outputs.summary: Publish to an NATS subject.
outputs.description:
This output will interpolate functions within the subject field, you can find a list of functions xref:configuration:interpolation.adoc#bloblang-queries[here].

== Connection name

When monitoring and managing a production NATS system, it is often useful to
know which connection a message was send/received from. This can be achieved by
setting the connection name option when creating a NATS connection.

Redpanda Connect will automatically set the connection name based off the label of the given
NATS component, so that monitoring tools between NATS and Redpanda Connect can stay in sync.


== Authentication

There are several components within Redpanda Connect which uses NATS services. You will find that each of these components
support optional advanced authentication parameters for https://docs.nats.io/nats-server/configuration/securing_nats/auth_intro/nkey_auth[NKeys^]
and https://docs.nats.io/using-nats/developer/connecting/creds[User Credentials^].

See an https://docs.nats.io/running-a-nats-service/nats_admin/security/jwt[in-depth tutorial^].

=== NKey file

The NATS server can use these NKeys in several ways for authentication. The simplest is for the server to be configured
with a list of known public keys and for the clients to respond to the challenge by signing it with its private NKey
configured in the `nkey_file` or `nkey` field.

https://docs.nats.io/running-a-nats-service/configuration/securing_nats/auth_intro/nkey_auth[More details^].

=== User credentials

NATS server supports decentralized authentication based on JSON Web Tokens (JWT). Clients need an https://docs.nats.io/nats-server/configuration/securing_nats/jwt#json-web-tokens[user JWT^]
and a corresponding https://docs.nats.io/running-a-nats-service/configuration/securing_nats/auth_intro/nkey_auth[NKey secret^] when connecting to a server
which is configured to use this authentication scheme.

The `user_credentials_file` field should point to a file containing both the private key and the JWT and can be
generated with the https://docs.nats.io/nats-tools/nsc[nsc tool^].

Alternatively, the `user_jwt` field can contain a plain text JWT and the `user_nkey_seed`can contain
the plain text NKey Seed.

https://docs.nats.io/using-nats/developer/connecting/creds[More details^].

====

and a corresponding https://docs.nats.io/running-a-nats-service/configuration/securing_nats/auth_intro/nkey_auth[NKey secret^] when connecting to a server
which is configured to use this authentication scheme.

The `user_credentials_file` field should point to a file containing both the private key and the JWT and can be
generated with the https://docs.nats.io/nats-tools/nsc[nsc tool^].

Alternatively, the `user_jwt` field can contain a plain text JWT and the `user_nkey_seed`can contain
the plain text NKey Seed.

https://docs.nats.io/using-nats/developer/connecting/creds[More details^].

== Performance

This output benefits from sending multiple messages in flight in parallel for improved performance. You can tune the max number of in flight messages (or message batches) with the field `max_in_flight`.

children.name: max_in_flight
children.description: The maximum number of batches to be sending in parallel at any given time.

children.name: batching
children.description: Allows you to configure a xref:configuration:batching.adoc[batching policy].

children.name: count
children.description: A number of messages at which the batch should be flushed. If `0` disables count based batching.

children.name: byte_size
children.description: An amount of bytes at which the batch should be flushed. If `0` disables size based batching.

children.name: period
children.description: A period in which an incomplete batch should be flushed regardless of its size.

children.name: check
children.description: A xref:guides:bloblang/about.adoc[Bloblang query] that should return a boolean value indicating whether a message should end a batch.

children.name: processors
children.description: A list of xref:components:processors/about.adoc[processors] to apply to a batch as it is flushed. This allows you to aggregate and archive the batch however you see fit. Please note that all resulting messages are flushed as a single batch, therefore splitting the batch into smaller batches using these processors is a no-op.

children.name: partitioner
children.description: Override the default murmur2 hashing partitioner.
annotated_options: Chooses the least backed up partition (the partition with the fewest amount of buffered records). Partitions are selected per batch.
Manually select a partition for each message, requires the field `partition` to be specified.
Kafka's default hash algorithm that uses a 32-bit murmur2 hash of the key to compute which partition the record will be on.

Round-robin's messages through all available partitions. This algorithm has lower throughput and causes higher CPU load on brokers, but can be useful if you want to ensure an even distribution of records to partitions.

children.name: idempotent_write
children.description: Enable the idempotent write producer option. This requires the `IDEMPOTENT_WRITE` permission on `CLUSTER` and can be disabled if this permission is not available.

children.name: compression
children.description: Optionally set an explicit compression type. The default preference is to use snappy when the broker supports it, and fall back to none if not.

children.name: allow_auto_topic_creation
children.description: Enables topics to be auto created if they do not exist when fetching their metadata.

children.name: timeout
children.description: The maximum period of time to wait for message sends before abandoning the request and retrying

children.name: max_message_bytes
children.description: The maximum space in bytes than an individual message may take, messages larger than this value will be rejected. This field corresponds to Kafka's `max.message.bytes`.

children.name: broker_write_max_bytes
children.description: The upper bound for the number of bytes written to a broker connection in a single write. This field corresponds to Kafka's `socket.request.max.bytes`.

children.name: topic
children.description: A topic to write messages to.

children.name: key
children.description: An optional key to populate for each message.

children.name: partition
children.description: An optional explicit partition to set for each message. This field is only relevant when the `partitioner` is set to `manual`. The provided interpolation string must be a valid integer.

children.name: metadata
children.description: Determine which (if any) metadata values should be added to messages as headers.

children.name: include_prefixes
children.description: Provide a list of explicit metadata key prefixes to match against.

children.name: include_patterns
children.description: Provide a list of explicit metadata key regular expression (re2) patterns to match against.

children.name: timestamp
children.description: An optional timestamp to set for each message. When left empty, the current timestamp is used.

children.name: timestamp_ms
children.description: An optional timestamp to set for each message expressed in milliseconds. When left empty, the current timestamp is used.

children.name: encrypted_fields
children.description: The fields to encrypt in the kafka messages, assuming the record is a valid JSON map. By default, the whole record is encrypted.

outputs.name: opensearch
outputs.summary: Publishes messages into an Elasticsearch index. If the index does not exist then it is created with a dynamic mapping.
outputs.description:
Both the `id` and `index` fields can be dynamically set using function interpolations described xref:configuration:interpolation.adoc#bloblang-queries[here]. When sending batched messages these interpolations are performed per message part.

== Performance

This output benefits from sending multiple messages in flight in parallel for improved performance. You can tune the max number of in flight messages (or message batches) with the field `max_in_flight`.

This output benefits from sending messages as a batch for improved performance. Batches can be formed at both the input and output level. You can find out more xref:configuration:batching.adoc[in this doc].

examples.title: Updating Documents
examples.summary: When https://opensearch.org/docs/latest/api-reference/document-apis/update-document/[updating documents^] the request body should contain a combination of a `doc`, `upsert`, and/or `script` fields at the top level, this should be done via mapping processors.
examples.config:
output:
  processors:
    - mapping: |
        meta id = this.id
        root.doc = this
  opensearch:
    urls: [ TODO ]
    index: foo
    id: ${! @id }
    action: update

outputs.name: redis_hash
outputs.summary: Sets Redis hash objects using the HMSET command.
outputs.description:
The field `key` supports xref:configuration:interpolation.adoc#bloblang-queries[interpolation functions], allowing you to create a unique key for each message.

The field `fields` allows you to specify an explicit map of field names to interpolated values, also evaluated per message of a batch:

```yaml
output:
  redis_hash:
    url: tcp://localhost:6379
    key: ${!json("id")}
    fields:
      topic: ${!meta("kafka_topic")}
      partition: ${!meta("kafka_partition")}
      content: ${!json("document.text")}
```

If the field `walk_metadata` is set to `true` then Redpanda Connect will walk all metadata fields of messages and add them to the list of hash fields to set.

If the field `walk_json_object` is set to `true` then Redpanda Connect will walk each message as a JSON object, extracting keys and the string representation of their value and adds them to the list of hash fields to set.

The order of hash field extraction is as follows:

1. Metadata (if enabled)
2. JSON object (if enabled)
3. Explicit fields

Where latter stages will overwrite matching field names of a former stage.

== Performance

This output benefits from sending multiple messages in flight in parallel for improved performance. You can tune the max number of in flight messages (or message batches) with the field `max_in_flight`.

children.name: tls
children.description:
Custom TLS settings can be used to override system defaults.

**Troubleshooting**

Some cloud hosted instances of Redis (such as Azure Cache) might need some hand holding in order to establish stable connections. Unfortunately, it is often the case that TLS issues will manifest as generic error messages such as "i/o timeout". If you're using TLS and are seeing connectivity problems consider setting `enable_renegotiation` to `true`, and ensuring that the server supports at least TLS version 1.2.

outputs.name: redis_streams
outputs.summary: Pushes messages to a Redis (v5.0+) Stream (which is created if it doesn't already exist) using the XADD command.
outputs.description:
It's possible to specify a maximum length of the target stream by setting it to a value greater than 0, in which case this cap is applied only when Redis is able to remove a whole macro node, for efficiency.

Redis stream entries are key/value pairs, as such it is necessary to specify the key to be set to the body of the message. All metadata fields of the message will also be set as key/value pairs, if there is a key collision between a metadata item and the body then the body takes precedence.

children.name: partitioner
children.description: Override the default murmur2 hashing partitioner.
annotated_options: Chooses the least backed up partition (the partition with the fewest amount of buffered records). Partitions are selected per batch.
Manually select a partition for each message, requires the field `partition` to be specified.
Kafka's default hash algorithm that uses a 32-bit murmur2 hash of the key to compute which partition the record will be on.

Round-robin's messages through all available partitions. This algorithm has lower throughput and causes higher CPU load on brokers, but can be useful if you want to ensure an even distribution of records to partitions.

children.name: idempotent_write
children.description: Enable the idempotent write producer option. This requires the `IDEMPOTENT_WRITE` permission on `CLUSTER` and can be disabled if this permission is not available.

children.name: compression
children.description: Optionally set an explicit compression type. The default preference is to use snappy when the broker supports it, and fall back to none if not.

children.name: allow_auto_topic_creation
children.description: Enables topics to be auto created if they do not exist when fetching their metadata.

children.name: timeout
children.description: The maximum period of time to wait for message sends before abandoning the request and retrying

children.name: max_message_bytes
children.description: The maximum space in bytes than an individual message may take, messages larger than this value will be rejected. This field corresponds to Kafka's `max.message.bytes`.

children.name: broker_write_max_bytes
children.description: The upper bound for the number of bytes written to a broker connection in a single write. This field corresponds to Kafka's `socket.request.max.bytes`.

outputs.name: redpanda_common
outputs.summary: Sends data to a Redpanda (Kafka) broker, using credentials defined in a common top-level `redpanda` config block.

examples.title: Simple Output
examples.summary: Data is generated and written to a topic bar, targetting the cluster configured within the redpanda block at the bottom. This is useful as it allows us to configure TLS and SASL only once for potentially multiple inputs and outputs.
examples.config:
input:
  generate:
    interval: 1s
    mapping: 'root.name = fake("name")'

pipeline:
  processors:
    - mutation: |
        root.id = uuid_v4()
        root.loud_name = this.name.uppercase()

output:
  redpanda_common:
    topic: bar
    key: ${! @id }

redpanda:
  seed_brokers: [ "127.0.0.1:9092" ]
  tls:
    enabled: true
  sasl:
    - mechanism: SCRAM-SHA-512
      password: bar
      username: foo

children.name: topic
children.description: A topic to write messages to.

children.name: key
children.description: An optional key to populate for each message.

children.name: partition
children.description: An optional explicit partition to set for each message. This field is only relevant when the `partitioner` is set to `manual`. The provided interpolation string must be a valid integer.

children.name: metadata
children.description: Determine which (if any) metadata values should be added to messages as headers.

children.name: include_prefixes
children.description: Provide a list of explicit metadata key prefixes to match against.

children.name: include_patterns
children.description: Provide a list of explicit metadata key regular expression (re2) patterns to match against.

children.name: timestamp
children.description: An optional timestamp to set for each message. When left empty, the current timestamp is used.

children.name: timestamp_ms
children.description: An optional timestamp to set for each message expressed in milliseconds. When left empty, the current timestamp is used.

children.name: max_in_flight
children.description: The maximum number of messages to have in flight at a given time. Increase this to improve throughput.

children.name: batching
children.description: Allows you to configure a xref:configuration:batching.adoc[batching policy].

children.name: count
children.description: A number of messages at which the batch should be flushed. If `0` disables count based batching.

children.name: byte_size
children.description: An amount of bytes at which the batch should be flushed. If `0` disables size based batching.

children.name: period
children.description: A period in which an incomplete batch should be flushed regardless of its size.

children.name: check
children.description: A xref:guides:bloblang/about.adoc[Bloblang query] that should return a boolean value indicating whether a message should end a batch.

children.name: processors
children.description: A list of xref:components:processors/about.adoc[processors] to apply to a batch as it is flushed. This allows you to aggregate and archive the batch however you see fit. Please note that all resulting messages are flushed as a single batch, therefore splitting the batch into smaller batches using these processors is a no-op.

outputs.name: redpanda_migrator
outputs.summary: A Redpanda Migrator output using the https://github.com/twmb/franz-go[Franz Kafka client library^].
outputs.description:
Writes a batch of messages to a Kafka broker and waits for acknowledgement before propagating it back to the input.

This output should be used in combination with a `redpanda_migrator` input identified by the label specified in
`input_resource` which it can query for topic and ACL configurations. Once connected, the output will attempt to
create all topics which the input consumes from along with their ACLs.

If the configured broker does not contain the current message topic, this output attempts to create it along with its
ACLs.

ACL migration adheres to the following principles:

- `ALLOW WRITE` ACLs for topics are not migrated
- `ALLOW ALL` ACLs for topics are downgraded to `ALLOW READ`
- Only topic ACLs are migrated, group ACLs are not migrated

examples.title: Transfer data
examples.summary: Writes messages to the configured broker and creates topics and topic ACLs if they don't exist. It also ensures that the message order is preserved.

children.name: partitioner
children.description: Override the default murmur2 hashing partitioner.
annotated_options: Chooses the least backed up partition (the partition with the fewest amount of buffered records). Partitions are selected per batch.
Manually select a partition for each message, requires the field `partition` to be specified.
Kafka's default hash algorithm that uses a 32-bit murmur2 hash of the key to compute which partition the record will be on.

Round-robin's messages through all available partitions. This algorithm has lower throughput and causes higher CPU load on brokers, but can be useful if you want to ensure an even distribution of records to partitions.

outputs.name: reject
outputs.summary: Rejects all messages, treating them as though the output destination failed to publish them.
outputs.description:
The routing of messages after this output depends on the type of input it came from. For inputs that support propagating nacks upstream such as AMQP or NATS the message will be nacked. However, for inputs that are sequential such as files or Kafka the messages will simply be reprocessed from scratch.

To learn when this output could be useful, see [the <<examples>>.

examples.title: Rejecting Failed Messages
examples.summary: This input is particularly useful for routing messages that have failed during processing, where instead of routing them to some sort of dead letter queue we wish to push the error upstream. We can do this with a switch broker:
examples.config:
output:
  switch:
    retry_until_success: false
    cases:
      - check: '!errored()'
        output:
          amqp_1:
            urls: [ amqps://guest:guest@localhost:5672/ ]
            target_address: queue:/the_foos

      - output:
          reject: "processing failed due to: ${! error() }"

outputs.name: reject_errored
outputs.summary: Rejects messages that have failed their processing steps, resulting in nack behavior at the input level, otherwise sends them to a child output.
outputs.description: The routing of messages rejected by this output depends on the type of input it came from. For inputs that support propagating nacks upstream such as AMQP or NATS the message will be nacked. However, for inputs that are sequential such as files or Kafka the messages will simply be reprocessed from scratch.

examples.title: Rejecting Failed Messages
examples.summary: The most straight forward use case for this output type is to nack messages that have failed their processing steps. In this example our mapping might fail, in which case the messages that failed are rejected and will be nacked by our input:
examples.config:
input:
  nats_jetstream:
    urls: [ nats://127.0.0.1:4222 ]
    subject: foos.pending

pipeline:
  processors:
    - mutation: 'root.age = this.fuzzy.age.int64()'

output:
  reject_errored:
    nats_jetstream:
      urls: [ nats://127.0.0.1:4222 ]
      subject: foos.processed

examples.title: DLQing Failed Messages
examples.summary: Another use case for this output is to send failed messages straight into a dead-letter queue. You use it within a xref:components:outputs/fallback.adoc[fallback output] that allows you to specify where these failed messages should go to next.
examples.config:
pipeline:
  processors:
    - mutation: 'root.age = this.fuzzy.age.int64()'

output:
  fallback:
    - reject_errored:
        http_client:
          url: http://foo:4195/post/might/become/unreachable
          retries: 3
          retry_period: 1s
    - http_client:
        url: http://bar:4196/somewhere/else
        retries: 3
        retry_period: 1s

outputs.name: resource
outputs.summary: Resource is an output type that channels messages to a resource output, identified by its name.
outputs.description:
Resources allow you to tidy up deeply nested configs. For example, the config:

```yaml
output:
  broker:
    pattern: fan_out
    outputs:
    - kafka:
        addresses: [ TODO ]
        topic: foo
    - gcp_pubsub:
        project: bar
        topic: baz
```

Could also be expressed as:

```yaml
output:
  broker:
    pattern: fan_out
    outputs:
    - resource: foo
    - resource: bar

output_resources:
  - label: foo
    kafka:
      addresses: [ TODO ]
      topic: foo

  - label: bar
    gcp_pubsub:
      project: bar
      topic: baz
```

You can find out more about resources in xref:configuration:resources.adoc[]

outputs.name: retry
outputs.summary: Attempts to write messages to a child output and if the write fails for any reason the message is retried either until success or, if the retries or max elapsed time fields are non-zero, either is reached.
outputs.description:
All messages in Redpanda Connect are always retried on an output error, but this would usually involve propagating the error back to the source of the message, whereby it would be reprocessed before reaching the output layer once again.

This output type is useful whenever we wish to avoid reprocessing a message on the event of a failed send. We might, for example, have a deduplication processor that we want to avoid reapplying to the same message more than once in the pipeline.

Rather than retrying the same output you may wish to retry the send using a different output target (a dead letter queue). In which case you should instead use the xref:components:outputs/fallback.adoc[`fallback`] output type.

children.name: max_retries
children.description: The maximum number of retries before giving up on the request. If set to zero there is no discrete limit.

children.name: backoff
children.description: Control time intervals between retry attempts.

children.name: initial_interval
children.description: The initial period to wait between retry attempts.

children.name: max_interval
children.description: The maximum period to wait between retry attempts.

children.name: max_elapsed_time
children.description: The maximum period to wait before retry attempts are abandoned. If zero then no limit is used.

children.name: output
children.description: A child output.

outputs.name: schema_registry
outputs.summary: Publishes schemas to SchemaRegistry.
outputs.description:
== Performance

This output benefits from sending multiple messages in flight in parallel for improved performance. You can tune the max number of in flight messages (or message batches) with the field `max_in_flight`.

examples.title: Write schemas
examples.summary: Write schemas to a Schema Registry instance and log errors for schemas which already exist.
examples.config:
output:
  fallback:
    - schema_registry:
        url: http://localhost:8082
        subject: ${! @schema_registry_subject }
        subject_compatibility_level: ${! @schema_registry_subject_compatibility_level }
    - switch:
        cases:
          - check: '@fallback_error == "request returned status: 422"'
            output:
              drop: {}
              processors:
                - log:
                    message: |
                      Subject '${! @schema_registry_subject }' version ${! @schema_registry_version } already has schema: ${! content() }
          - output:
              reject: ${! @fallback_error }

children.description: The base URL of the schema registry service.

children.name: subject
children.description: Subject.

children.name: subject_compatibility_level
children.description: The compatibility level for the subject. Can be one of BACKWARD, BACKWARD_TRANSITIVE, FORWARD, FORWARD_TRANSITIVE, FULL, FULL_TRANSITIVE, NONE.

children.name: backfill_dependencies
children.description: Backfill schema references and previous versions.

children.name: translate_ids
children.description: Translate schema IDs.

children.name: normalize
children.description: Normalize schemas.

children.name: remove_metadata
children.description: Remove metadata from schemas.

children.name: remove_rule_set
children.description: Remove rule set from schemas.

children.description: Whether to allow the remote server to repeatedly request renegotiation. Enable this option if you're seeing the error message `local error: tls: no renegotiation`.

children.name: root_cas
children.description: An optional root certificate authority to use. This is a string, representing a certificate chain from the parent trusted root certificate, to possible intermediate signing certificates, to the host certificate.

children.name: root_cas_file
children.description: An optional path of a root certificate authority file to use. This is a file, often with a .pem extension, containing a certificate chain from the parent trusted root certificate, to possible intermediate signing certificates, to the host certificate.

children.name: client_certs
children.description: A list of client certificates to use. For each certificate either the fields `cert` and `key`, or `cert_file` and `key_file` should be specified, but not both.

children.name: cert
children.description: A plain text certificate to use.

children.name: key
children.description: A plain text certificate key to use.

children.name: cert_file
children.description: The path of a certificate to use.

children.name: key_file
children.description: The path of a certificate key to use.

children.name: password
children.description:
A plain text password for when the private key is password encrypted in PKCS#1 or PKCS#8 format. The obsolete `pbeWithMD5AndDES-CBC` algorithm is not supported for the PKCS#8 format.

Because the obsolete pbeWithMD5AndDES-CBC algorithm does not authenticate the ciphertext, it is vulnerable to padding oracle attacks that can let an attacker recover the plaintext.

children.name: max_in_flight
children.description: The maximum number of messages to have in flight at a given time. Increase this to improve throughput.

children.name: oauth
children.description: Allows you to specify open authentication via OAuth version 1.

children.name: enabled
children.description: Whether to use OAuth version 1 in requests.

children.name: consumer_key
children.description: A value used to identify the client to the service provider.

children.name: consumer_secret
children.description: A secret used to establish ownership of the consumer key.

children.name: access_token
children.description: A value used to gain access to the protected resources on behalf of the user.

children.name: access_token_secret
children.description: A secret provided in order to establish ownership of a given access token.

children.name: basic_auth
children.description: Allows you to specify basic authentication.

children.name: enabled
children.description: Whether to use basic authentication in requests.

children.name: username
children.description: A username to authenticate as.

children.name: password
children.description: A password to authenticate with.

children.name: jwt
children.description: BETA: Allows you to specify JWT authentication.

children.name: enabled
children.description: Whether to use JWT authentication in requests.

children.name: private_key_file
children.description: A file with the PEM encoded via PKCS1 or PKCS8 as private key.

children.name: signing_method
children.description: A method used to sign the token such as RS256, RS384, RS512 or EdDSA.

children.name: claims
children.description: A value used to identify the claims that issued the JWT.

children.name: headers
children.description: Add optional key/value headers to the JWT.

outputs.name: sftp
outputs.summary: Writes files to an SFTP server.
outputs.description:
In order to have a different path for each object you should use function interpolations described xref:configuration:interpolation.adoc#bloblang-queries[here].

== Performance

This output benefits from sending multiple messages in flight in parallel for improved performance. You can tune the max number of in flight messages (or message batches) with the field `max_in_flight`.

children.name: address
children.description: The address of the server to connect to.

children.name: connection_timeout
children.description: The connection timeout to use when connecting to the target server.

children.name: credentials
children.description: The credentials to use to log into the target server.

children.name: username
children.description: The username to authenticate with the SFTP server.

children.name: password
children.description: The password for the specified username to connect to the SFTP server.

children.name: host_public_key_file
children.description: The path to the SFTP server's public key file, used for host key verification.

children.name: host_public_key
children.description: The raw contents of the SFTP server's public key, used for host key verification.

children.name: private_key_file
children.description: The path to the private key file, used for authenticating the username.

children.name: private_key
children.description: The raw contents of the private key, used for authenticating the username.

children.name: private_key_pass
children.description: Optional passphrase for decrypting the private key, if it's encrypted.

children.name: path
children.description: The file to save the messages to on the server.

children.name: codec
children.description: The way in which the bytes of messages should be written out into the output data stream. It's possible to write lines using a custom delimiter with the `delim:x` codec, where x is the character sequence custom delimiter.
annotated_options: Only applicable to file based outputs. Writes each message to a file in full, if the file already exists the old content is deleted.
Append each message to the output stream without any delimiter or special encoding.
Append each message to the output stream followed by a custom delimiter.
Append each message to the output stream followed by a line break.

children.name: max_in_flight
children.description: The maximum number of messages to have in flight at a given time. Increase this to improve throughput.

outputs.name: slack_post
outputs.description: Post a new message to a Slack channel using https://api.slack.com/methods/chat.postMessage[^chat.postMessage]

examples.title: Echo Slackbot
examples.summary: A slackbot that echo messages from other users
examples.config:
input:
  slack:
    app_token: "${APP_TOKEN:xapp-demo}"
    bot_token: "${BOT_TOKEN:xoxb-demo}"
pipeline:
  processors:
    - mutation: |
        # ignore hidden or non message events
        if this.event.type != "message" || (this.event.hidden | false) {
          root = deleted()
        }
        # Don't respond to our own messages
        if this.authorizations.any(auth -> auth.user_id == this.event.user) {
          root = deleted()
        }
output:
  slack_post:
    bot_token: "${BOT_TOKEN:xoxb-demo}"
    channel_id: "${!this.event.channel}"
    thread_ts: "${!this.event.ts}"
    text: "ECHO: ${!this.event.text}"

children.name: bot_token
children.description: The Slack Bot User OAuth token to use.
children.linter: root = if !this.has_prefix("xoxb-") { [ "field must start with xoxb-" ] }

children.name: channel_id
children.description: The channel ID to post messages to.

children.name: thread_ts
children.description: Optional thread timestamp to post messages to.

children.name: text
children.description: The text content of the message. Mutually exclusive with `blocks`.

children.name: blocks
children.description: A Bloblang query that should return a JSON array of Slack blocks (see https://api.slack.com/reference/block-kit/blocks[Blocks in Slack documentation]). Mutually exclusive with `text`.

children.name: markdown
children.description: Enable markdown formatting in the message.

children.name: unfurl_links
children.description: Enable link unfurling in the message.

children.name: unfurl_media
children.description: Enable media unfurling in the message.

children.name: link_names
children.description: Enable link names in the message.

children.name: bot_token
children.description: The Slack Bot User OAuth token to use.

children.name: channel_id
children.description: The channel ID containing the message to react to.

children.name: timestamp

children.name: emoji
